description:
On March 31, The Ministry of Education and Higher Education (MOEHE) of Qatar issued a distance learning plan for academic subjects for the 2019-2020 academic year for grades 1 to 12.

Each chapter has a detailed explanation of the unit of study and the materials that fall under it, as well as the number of classes for each lesson, with the specified page numbers determined, in order to facilitate the educational process for all students.

Students can also follow their educational lessons remotely on Qatar TV via Badr 4, Frequency: 12169, Polarisation: Vertical, Error Correction: 3/4; Symbol Rate: 22000.

The ministry explained that through the distance learning plan, the weekly evaluation will be after the end of the last session of a subject according to the weekly schedule, while giving the student a week to answer. UPDATE: The MOEHE announced this policy would end on May 7.

description: On April 21, 2020, Qatar's Ministry of Endowment and Islamic Affairs (Awqaf) said it will implement its Ramadan programs this year via electronic platforms affiliated with the Ministry or via the known social media websites, such as Facebook, Twitter and Instagram on the Ministry’s account. This is in the light of the full closure of the mosques in the State of Qatar as a precautionary measure to curb the spread of the Coronavirus (COVID-19). His Eminence Sheikh Malallah Al Jabir, Director of  Department of Da'wah and Religious Guidance affiliated with Awqaf, has said that the Ministry has been prepared to implement a number of Da’wah (preaching Islam) and awareness programs, since the Ministry has been keen to implement these distance programs by using technology and integrated electronic system.

description: All Qatar residents will be required to wear face masks outside of their homes beginning Sunday, May 17, to curb the spread of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19). The only exception applies to those driving in a car with no other passengers. Those who fail to comply with the measures will be sanctioned, either with a maximum of three days in prison and/or a fine of QR 200,000 (USD 55,000). Previously, masks were compulsory for employees of select sectors and in some public spaces. UPDATE: On Wednesday, Qatar’s cabinet said that starting from October 3, mask regulations would no longer apply to outdoor activities, except during organised public events, markets and exhibitions. However, it added that masks must still be worn at mosques, schools, hospitals and university premises, as well as at all public indoor areas.
